title: FOIA - ELERTS Corp Documents (Bay Area Rapid Transit Police)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: FOIA - ELERTS Corp Documents (Bay Area Rapid Transit Police)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All documents pertaining to the your agency's contract with ELERTS Corporation (https://elerts.com/). These documents might include, but are not limited to, the following:

- Initial Bid Documents
- Current and previous contracts with Motorola regarding ELERTS
- Requests for Proposals
- Memorandum(s) of Understanding
- Any privacy impact assessments
- Any product manuals
- Any instructional materials or presentations
- Use policies and standard operating procedures
- Data retention policies
- Letters of Interest
- Usage policies
- Any informal agreements or other documents that reference "ELERTS" or otherwise guide it use or the relationship between this agency and the provider or developer of the software.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

J Ader

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Tree trimming (Mayor's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Public statements show that the City Controller has investigated tree trimming near Lakeside Drive & Barham Boulevard:

https://twitter.com/lacontroller/status/1681456457936687104
https://abc7.com/los-angeles-tree-trimming-universal-studios-strike/13521870/

Therefore, I request the following:

- The results of this investigation and any documents used to perform the investigation
- Any communications that mention "Universal Studios" or "Universal" sent between July 1, 2023 and the time this request is processed, including attachments
- Any communications between the city and "@nbcuni.com" email addresses sent between July 1, 2023, and the time this request is processed, including attachments
- Any formal requests from Universal to obtain permits to trim trees between 2018 and 2023.
- Any photos, videos, or audio recordings taken by the city of this area in July 2023
- Any communications between the city and "@sagaftra.org" email addresses between July 17, 2023 and the time this request is processed.
- Any city documents about the specific management of these trees

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jason Koebler

title: Washington Public Records Act Request: Tuberculosis case notification data and related policies, 2000-2022

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Washington Public Records Act Request: Tuberculosis case notification data and related policies, 2000-2022
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:


*  Records of TB case notifications in all Washington state prisons, with day and institution of notification for each case from January 2020-July 2022.
* Records of date of TB treatment initiation for all notified cases.
* Records ofTB treatment outcomes for all notified cases. 
* Records of number of and location of incarcerated individuals offered TB testing and number of individuals who were tested and date of testing.
* Records of TB case notifications in all Washington state prisons for corrections officers in all WA state prisons, with day and institution of notification for each case from January 2020-July 2022.
* Records of number of and location of corrections officers offered TB testing and number of individuals who were tested.
* Any and all WDOC policies and procedures regarding TB prevention and control measures put in place in prisons.
* Records of movements of incarcerated individuals from or to any of the prisons reporting TB cases from January 2020-July 2022, including the number of individuals transferred, date of transfer, reason of transfer, origin prison, and destination prison.

For all items, we are requesting de-identified records.


The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. Further, we respectfully request a waiver of these fees as we are affiliated with a research institution, and this request is made for a scholarly or scientific purpose and not for a commercial use. We would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Katharine Walter

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request: Washington Public Records Act Request: Tuberculosis case notification data and related policies, 2000-2022
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Washington Public Records Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on July 19, 2022. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: Public Records Request, P-29139
communications.communication:
Ms. Walter:

I acknowledge receipt of your public records request dated July 18, 2022 and received in our office on July 19, 2022. We have assigned this request a tracking number of P-29139.  Please reference this number in all future communications regarding this request.

You state your request to be for the following records:

1.      Records of TB case notifications in all Washington state prisons, with day and institution of notification for each case from January 2020‐July 2022
2.      Records of date of TB treatment initiation for all notified cases
3.      Records of TB treatment outcomes for all notified cases
4.      Records of number of and location of incarcerated individuals offered TB testing and number of individuals who were tested and date of testing
5.      Records of TB case notifications in all Washington state prisons for corrections officers in all WA state prisons, with day and institution of notification for each case from January 2020‐July 2022
6.      Records of number of and location of corrections officers offered TB testing and number of individuals who were tested
7.      Any and all WDOC policies and procedures regarding TB prevention and control measures put in place in prisons
8.      Records of movements of incarcerated individuals from or to any of the prisons reporting TB cases from January 2020‐July 2022, including the number of individuals transferred, date of transfer, reason of transfer, origin prison, and destination prison

I interpret your request to be for disclosure of the following records:

1.      Records showing TB case notifications from the time frame of January 1, 2020, to July 19, 2022 (the date your request was received) in all Washington state prisons, including date and facility location
2.      Records showing date of TB treatment initiation for all notified cases
3.      Records showing all TB treatment outcomes for all notified cases
4.      Records showing number of, and facility location of incarcerated individuals offered TB testing including number of individuals who were tested and date of testing
5.      Records showing TB case notifications from the time frame of January 1, 2020, to July 19, 2022 (the date your request was received) in all Washington state prisons for corrections officers in all Washington state prisons, including date and facility location
6.      Records showing number of, and facility location of corrections officers offered TB testing and number of individuals who were tested
7.      Any and all current g Washington State Department of Corrections policies and procedures regarding TB prevention and control measures put in place in prisons
8.      Records showing movements of incarcerated individuals from or to any of the prison facilities reporting TB cases during the time frame of January 1, 2020 to July 19 2022, (the date your request was received) including the number of individuals transferred, date of transfer, reason for transfer, origin facility, and receiving facility

I will begin by determining what if any of this information exists outside of confidential individual health records and gather what is available outside of these protected records.   I anticipate being able to provide you an installment of records within 46 business days, on or before August 29, 2022. If you have any questions in the interim, please contact me at tonja.monroe@doc1.wa.gov<mailto:tonja.monroe@doc1.wa.gov>.

Sincerely,

Tonja Monroe, Public Records Specialist
Public Records Unit
Washington State Department of Corrections
PO Box 41118
Olympia WA 98504-1118

TM:  P-29139

Public Records Unit
Washington State Department of Corrections

Dear Tonja,

Thank you for your response and attention to this matter. Yes, I am confirming your interpretation of our request above. 

We understand the patient privacy concerns this request may generate. De-identified records and data would be perfectly sufficient to satisfy our needs. Please do not hesitate to reach out if there are any additional clarifications. Thank you again for your help with this request.

Sincerely,

Katharine Walter, PhD

Postdoctoral Fellow
Stanford University School of Medicine
300 Pasteur Drive, L-134
Stanford CA, 94305
Division of Infectious Diseases

Tonja Monroe, Public Records Specialist

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #P-29139
communications.communication:
Dear Tonja, 

Thank you very much for your email and for sending item 7 on the list, the policies and procedures regarding TB prevention and control measures put in place in prisons. 

We look forward to the next installment. If you are able to send any part of the installment earlier, that would be great. We are most specifically interested in records of the number and location of TB cases and TB infections in 2021 and 2022. If you are able to prioritize those, we would be most appreciative.

Thank you very much for your help.

All the best,
Katharine S. Walter

communications.subject: Public records request, P-29139 Installment #3
communications.communication:
Ms. Walter:

This e-mail is in follow-up to my last correspondence to you, dated January 19, 2023, regarding your public records request, P-29139.  You requested the following records:

1.      Records showing TB case notifications from the time frame of January 1, 2020, to July 19, 2022 (the date your request was received) in all Washington state prisons, including date and facility location
2.      Records showing date of TB treatment initiation for all notified cases
3.      Records showing all TB treatment outcomes for all notified cases
4.      Records showing number of, and facility location of incarcerated individuals offered TB testing including number of individuals who were tested and date of testing
5.      Records showing TB case notifications from the time frame of January 1, 2020, to July 19, 2022 (the date your request was received) in all Washington state prisons for corrections officers in all Washington state prisons, including date and facility location
6.      Records showing number of, and facility location of corrections officers offered TB testing and number of individuals who were tested
7.      Any and all current Washington State Department of Corrections policies and procedures regarding TB prevention and control measures put in place in prisons
8.      Records showing movements of incarcerated individuals from or to any of the prison facilities reporting TB cases during the time frame of January 1, 2020 to July 19 2022, (the date your request was received) including the number of individuals transferred, date of transfer, reason for transfer, origin facility, and receiving facility

I have attached a 3rd installment of records (113 pages) consisting of records responsive to item 8 of your request. These documents are provided to you in accordance with the Public Records Act.  By providing you these documents and/or information, the Department is not responsible for your use of this information or for any claims or liabilities that may result from your use or further dissemination.

I will now begin processing installment #4 of P-29139.  I anticipate being able to provide an installment of records within 30 business days; on or before March 29, 2023.

Sincerely,

Tonja Monroe
Public Records Specialist
Department of Corrections | Public Records Unit
P.O. Box 41118 | Olympia, WA  98504-1118

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #P-29139
communications.communication:
Dear Tanja,

Thank you for your help with this request! We really appreciate it. We look forward to hearing back from you soon. In response to installation #2--this does not include notified cases of TB among incarcerated individuals, including date of notification and location (item 1 in our record request). Would you please additionally include that information in the next installment?

Thank you for your time.

Sincerely,
Katharine Walter

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #P-29139

Thank you,

Tonja Monroe

communications.communication:
Dear Tanja,

Thank you for your help with this request and we look forward to the complete data. 

In response to your email about item 1 in our record request, we understand that you are not able to provide individual records. To understand the epidemiology of the outbreak though, information on location of cases is essential. Would it be possible to include the de-identified number of cases and dates of case notifications per facility (item #1) as is routinely done for COVID-19 in Washington prisons? 

Thank you again for your time.

Sincerely,
Katharine Walter

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: ARREST CONSORTIUM
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am seeking records about COPLINK and the ARREST Consortium. Some of these records were once public on the ARREST Consortium website at arrest.spokanepolice.org, others are internal agency records. The records include:

- ARREST MOU
- ARREST User Access Request Form
- ARREST Access Request Policy
- Internal Memos and communications about Coplink Success Stories
- The  Detect User Guide
-  Active Agent User Guide
- Visualizer User Guide
- Incident Analyzer User Guide	How to use the Analyzer component of Coplink.
- A3 Interface User Guide		
- Case Folders User Guide
- A roster of individuals who completed a training to use COPLINK - the list should include the individuals department.
- Record of individuals with access to COPLINK - the list should include the individuals department.
- Coplink 4.0 Fast Track Sheet	A quick start guide to using COPLINK 4.0
- COPLINK FAQS	Frequently asked COPLINK Questions
- Emails, Internal Memos or Communications referencing COPLINK'S FACEMATCH
- Any power point presentation, Liason Tip, or training document about COPLINK
- Emails between COPLINK Law Enforcement Liason, Mike Widmer, as well any other COPLINK representative

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dhruv Mehrotra

communications.subject: [Records Center] City Records Request :: P001989-022323
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
If you wish to submit a response, update an existing request, check the status of an already submitted request, or submit a new public records request, please do so by replying to this notification or go through your “My Request Center” account on the City’s public records request portal 
This is a follow up to my July 25, 2023, message to you regarding your February 23, 2023, public records request assigned tracking number P001989-022323. 

This is to advise that a second installment of responsive records is available by accessing your account via the My Request Center on the City’s public records request portal (GovQA). 

This is to advise an additional record has been located by Police Department staff that pertains to your request, however, the record you are seeking includes a list of individuals. An appellate court decision, SEIU Healthcare 775 NW v. DSHS, 193 Wn. App. 377 (2016) holds that when a city receives a request for documents that includes a list of individuals, the City is required to determine whether the list will be used for “commercial purposes.” The case concluded that a requestor has a commercial purpose if the requestor intends to use the list for direct or indirect profit-making activity, regardless of whether the requestor intends to contact the individuals on the list or even if the individuals are personally affected by the release of the list or not. If the City has some indication that a requester intends to use a list of individuals for a commercial purpose, we are required to “investigate further” before we disclose that list. 
Further, the SEIU case held that even an affirmation stating that any responsive records received for a request which include lists of individuals will not be used for commercial purposes, is not sufficient.  Instead, before we can release the records providing the requested information, we are required to obtain from you sufficient details as to what you intend to use the list for so that we can make an independent evaluation as to whether or not your purpose is commercial or not. 

If you wish to obtain the record referenced above which includes a list of individuals, please fill out and return the Commercial Purpose Declaration which is available by accessing your account through the "My Request Center" on the City's public records request portal (GovQA). A determination will then be made as to whether your stated purpose regarding the use of the list(s) of individuals contained in any compiled responsive records is sufficient to allow for the release of this information. To avoid unnecessary delay in obtaining these specific responsive records for your request, please return the completed declaration at your earliest opportunity. We will follow up with you within five business days as to the validity of the stated purpose relating to your request. Upon determination that your completed declaration is valid, we anticipate providing these emails in your next installment. 

Please provide the completed affidavit as soon as possible, but within 30 days of today’s date, or by October 13, 2023. If we have not heard back from you in this regard by that date, we will be unable to provide you with the record located that include a list of individuals. 

Staff is still in the process of reviewing the records located by Police Department staff. Per section 18 on page 9 of the contract being provided to you via your GovQA account, we are required to notify Forensic Logic LLC. of your public records request and provide them with the opportunity pursuant to RCW 42.56.540 (court protection of public records), to enjoin (stop) the City’s release of the responsive records. If no court ordered injunction is received from the company by the date prescribed to them, the records will be provided to you. 

We reasonably anticipate requiring approximately 50 days, or until on or about November 2, 2023, to provide a next installment for your request. We will follow up with you on or about that date regarding the status of your request. If responsive records become available in advance of this estimate, we will let you know. Conversely, if City staff encounters a need to extend our estimate, we will advise accordingly. 
Sincerely, 
Sabrina Groves 
Administrative Specialist

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #P001989-022323
communications.communication:
Hi Sabrina, 

As a reporter for the WIRED, a national technology publication, I qualify as a news media requester under federal records laws see 5 U.S.C. 552(a)(4)(A)(ii). Further, this request is being made for a journalistic purpose regarding a matter of public interest,  See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). Disclosure of information regarding this technology is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of how police departments use Coplink. This request is not primarily in the commercial interest of myself or WIRED.

communications.subject: [Records Center] City Records Request :: P001989-022323
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
If you wish to submit a response, update an existing request, check the status of an already submitted request, or submit a new public records request, please do so by replying to this notification or go through your “My Request Center” account on the City’s public records request portal (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=6HtRfOYLt5fXvpttM-2FU1HSVD4CrS9uFW2stupoI-2F3P-2FCR9v4w4dDGSabyWOuZGyK73EIPwhayp6yerTiw-2FMwyAatRlrvnO7ENj4b1rLl3GE-3DmWoO_dN85cf6j7f1LcJCnNAUB0PEsQAaLAZkOaugrLy24sRwsylTqlztcxuVKNmxx1RslgoTtntqOo-2FNdiT1Y8IhVpyyhthR8nLBqrf-2FrlYGO4sLPFaAafN0Yt-2F-2FCNYQLF7A-2BNr-2Bd5VMqUlCKwdD70pRYV8aQK8QqqLzEwlJ-2Bh8FjF1VPGdoKxbXsqUdvD1ymcZN-2BK8A1w75yvbRgMDd01Q5n-2BCashYEDwyqpj-2FphtIiI6-2BysIWvx2FFTBfcrdOorK02tre-2B2kAlafthvDWfMpKF0y7fROulWFXUeiwANY5NSarhFTJCoYDkZxofAwyCk4fNLTzP1fi8bB563rmp5JI7zq1kTduzuxpV5cvo-2BGX70z5-2FVyB2TWglX5EVUPTU7-2BSjkn86UqrZimFLQrFEXwPvRnQ-3D-3D) 
This is a follow up to your September 14, 2023, message regarding your February 23, 2023, public records request assigned tracking number P001989-022323 wherein you state the following: 
Hi Sabrina, As a reporter for the WIRED, a national technology publication, I qualify as a news media requester under federal records laws see 5 U.S.C. 552(a)(4)(A)(ii). Further, this request is being made for a journalistic purpose regarding a matter of public interest, See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). Disclosure of information regarding this technology is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of how police departments use Coplink. This request is not primarily in the commercial interest of myself or WIRED. Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fspokane-police-department-717%252Farrest-consortium-141189%252F%253Femail%253Dspokanewa%252540govqa.us&url_auth_token=AAAkCQYMGrzer8VxLONpUgOmZfM%3A1qh0E7%3AdLWUdELmGgTd-WvdnFkRUnv1-Z0FxpzgXEVhkxW5iI8 

The PRA expressly states that a government agency “shall not… give, sell or provide access to lists of individuals requested for commercial purposes….”  RCW 42.56.070(8).  This statutory language impliedly burdens an agency to investigate further a requestor’s purpose and intended use for records containing a list of individuals.  Absent statutory guidance, agencies are left to consider each request on a case-by-case basis, as well as other factors, such as the identity of the requestor, the nature of the records requested, and any other information available to the agency. 

Agencies across the state may implement the requirements of the PRA differently.  Each agency bears its own liability for failure to comply with the PRA.  The language in RCW 42.56.070(8) is a clear prohibition on the release of lists of individuals for commercial purposes.  Therefore, it is the City’s position that requiring requestors complete the commercial purpose declaration satisfies the City’s obligation to investigate while also establishing a standard practice that can be applied to requestors. 

Due to the above, we hope you are amenable to completing the declaration and returning the completed form at your earliest convenience. 

As advised under my September 13 message to you, please provide the completed affidavit as soon as possible, or by October 13, 2023. If we have not received a completed and valid commercial purpose declaration from you by that date, we will be unable to release the record located that includes a list of individuals. 

Further, Staff is still in the process of reviewing the records located by Police Department staff. Per section 18 on page 9 of the contract being provided to you via your GovQA account, we are required to notify Forensic Logic LLC. of your public records request and provide them with the opportunity pursuant to RCW 42.56.540 (court protection of public records), to enjoin (stop) the City’s release of the responsive records. If no court ordered injunction is received from the company by the date prescribed to them, the records will be provided to you. 

We reasonably anticipate requiring until on or about November 2, 2023, to provide a next installment for your request. We will follow up with you on or about that date regarding the status of your request. If responsive records become available in advance of this estimate, we will let you know. Conversely, if City staff encounters a need to extend our estimate, we will advise accordingly. 

Sincerely, 

Sabrina Groves 
Administrative Specialist

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fspokane-police-department-717%252Farrest-consortium-141189%252F%253Femail%253Dspokanewa%252540govqa.us&url_auth_token=AAAkCQYMGrzer8VxLONpUgOmZfM%3A1qy4z4%3AmAEU1P1PQnJWqKRequ40hStqz1a7z0LQBeC0dOsGMeM

Some of the information in the provided records has been determined to be exempt from disclosure and that information has been redacted. An exemption log accompanies the records explaining the exempt information and the reasons and statutes relied upon for withholding the information. 

In accordance with Section 6.5 of the City’s Public Records Request policy, if you wish to appeal a determination to withhold information, you may petition in writing or by email to the City Clerk’s Office for a review of the determination within sixty (60) days of the denial of access.  Please include a copy of, or reasonably identify, the part of the response to which you object.  Your petition will be forwarded to the Hearing Examiner, who will consider the petition and either affirm or reverse the determination within ten (10) business days following the City’s receipt of the petition, or within such greater period of time as the City and the requestor mutually agree to. You may obtain a court review of the denial of your request pursuant to RCW 42.56.520 at the conclusion of the two business days after the initial denial, regardless of any internal administrative review.  The complete Public Records Request Policy may be accessed at the following website: https://my.spokanecity.org/administrative/public-records/.  

This request is now concluded and closed. If you feel we have overlooked anything in responding to your request or if we may be of further assistance, please advise. 

Sincerely, 

Sabrina Groves 
Administrative Specialist

communications.subject: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Dispatch Call (Reno Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting a dispatch call summary or transcript from August 31st, 2022 around 2:30 pm from 869 N. Sierra St dealing with an indecently dressed woman loitering on private property.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Mallory Loftus

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Officer time-off
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records sufficient to show the names, star numbers, respective dates, date requested, and the type of time off of all police officers and/or employees who requested any personal time off, vacation days, personal days, sick days, or any other time off for the dates of, on, or between July 19, 2023 and July 26, 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: FOIA request 1408874 (Daniel Bledsoe)
communications.communication:
Good morning Ms. Best,

We're contacting you about the FOIA request you made for records concerning Daniel Bledsoe. As you probably recall, the FBI located approximately 1330 pages that are potentially responsive to your request. Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system, and the FBI receives a voluminous amount of requests on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium (51-950 pages), large (951-8000 pages), and extra-large (over 8000 pages) sub-tracks based upon request size. 

Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  The more potentially responsive pages a request has, the more complex it becomes, greatly increasing the time required for processing.  Generally, the larger the file, the longer it takes to process. A review of your request determined that it is currently in the complex request large processing track.  Given our current workload and staffing levels, it may yet be a long time before you begin to receive material from this request.   

Reducing the scope of your request may accelerate the processing and allow for a more timely receipt of the information you seek, as it could potentially place your request into a smaller, faster processing track.  This may also reduce duplication costs, if applicable.  Would you be willing to consider reducing the scope of your request?  If so, I would be happy to help you to decide the best approach to take.  We could potentially narrow your request by date, or if you are looking for something specific, we could approach the scope reduction process in that way.

Please let us know if you would like to potentially reduce the scope of your request.  We can be reached via email at fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov, or you may call 540-868-1695, Monday - Friday between the hours of 7:00am and 3:00pm Eastern time.

Best regards,

FOIA Negotiation Team
FBI Information Management Division
540-868-1695

Need a status check? Contact FOIPA Questions (foipaquestions@fbi.gov).

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Daniel Bledsoe
communications.communication: I'm afraid I need the entire file. Can you please confirm that the fee request was made in error, and the Bureau will not be attempting to charge duplication fees for this request?

communications.communication:
Good morning Ms. Best,

You were granted news media status for this request, therefore there should be no fees because the page count is less than 5,000. We will continue processing the request in full. Thank you for following up.

Best regards,

FOIA Negotiation Team
FBI Information Management Division
540-868-1695

Need a status check? Contact FOIPA Questions (foipaquestions@fbi.gov).

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Iowa crop acreage data 2018-2022
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Iowa crop acreage data separated into three categories: planted; prevented planted; and failed. We request that the data be separated out by year for the specified timeframe of 2018-2022. The current public data compiles the categories together, but as indicated here: https://www.fsa.usda.gov/news-room/efoia/electronic-reading-room/frequently-requested-information/crop-acreage-data/index the FSA receives data from farmers in all categories individually.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Katherine Hapgood

communications.subject: Request: 2024-FSA-00564-F Hapgood-Final Response
communications.communication:
Ms. Hapgood,


This letter acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request (copy attached) dated October 29, 2023, to the Department of Agriculture (USDA) Farm Production and Conservation Business Center (FPAC-BC).  Your request was received in this office on October 30, 2023, and assigned control number 2024-FSA-00564-F. Please use this control number for all future communications regarding this request.


In response to your request for “Iowa crop acreage data separated into three categories: planted; prevented planted; and failed, from 2018-2022”, detailed records for crops, including records you are requesting, are currently available in the public domain and accessible through FSA’s public web site.  We are providing the link for you here: https://www.fsa.usda.gov/news-room/efoia/electronic-reading-room/frequently-requested-information/crop-acreage-data/index.

From the site, open the report(s), click on the county summary sheet on the bottom of the Excel spreadsheet.  You will find the information you are seeking, below is a snip of what you will see.

[cid:image001.png@01DA0D6C.8250BF90]


Request 2023-FSA-00564-F is officially closed.

We trust the information fully satisfies your request. If you have questions concerning this request, please contact Government Information (GI) Specialist Carol Nagel at 701-530-2107. If GI Specialist Carol Nagel is not available, please contact GI Specialist Christina Vander Linden at 816-823-2669, or GI Specialist Hani Nguyen at 763-388-0490. We can also be reached at the group e-mail address SM.FP.FOIA@usda.gov<mailto:SM.FP.FOIA@usda.gov>.



Sincerely,

Patrick McLoughlin
Patrick McLoughlin
FOIA Officer
Farm Production and Conservation





This electronic message contains information generated by the USDA solely for the intended recipients. Any unauthorized interception of this message or the use or disclosure of the information it contains may violate the law and subject the violator to civil or criminal penalties. If you believe you have received this message in error, please notify the sender and delete the email immediately.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: NPRC JW 8.7.23
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

You are receiving this correspondence as a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. subsection 552. I am requesting the following:

All publicly releasable military and civilian records for Louis Jolyon West (October 6, 1924 – January 2, 1999). Mr. West's social security number was  395-16-2395. He served in the United States Air Force (USAF) between approximately 1948 and 1956, and worked as a civilian contractor at the 3700th USAF Hospital at the Lackland Air Force Base after that. Therefore, I am requesting the following information from Mr. West's Official Military Personnel File (OMPF) and his Official Personnel Folder (OPF). This information includes, but is not limited to:

• Name

• Service Number

• Certificate of Release/Discharge Papers, aka DD form 214

• Dates of Service

• Branch of Service

• Final Duty Status

• Final Rank

• Salary

• Assignments and Geographical Locations

• Source of Commission

• Military Education Level

• Awards and decorations

• Civilian positions

• Civilian titles

• Civilian salaries

• Civilian grades

• Civilian job locations

If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the National Personnel Records Center has no other copies of said records.

You will find as an attachment a copy of Mr. West's obituary from the The New York Times, published on January 9, 1999.

I am asking you waive any fees associated with this request. I am a member of the news media and request classification as such. My bylines, which include Creem Magazine, Covert Action Magazine, and the Geopolitical Economy Report, can be found in both print and electronic publications. Please take note of the Office of Management and Budget guidelines published March 27, 1987 (52 FR 10012) that include electronic publications and other nontraditional publishers as representatives of the news media.

A fee waiver is appropriate in situations where "disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations and activities of the government, and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester,” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(iii). Mr. West, per the attached obituary, was a figure of considerable public interest. He worked for the government, both during his time in the USAF and as a civilian contractor, during the Korean War, on research related to the alleged brainwashing of American prisoners-of-war, by Korean, Soviet, and Chinese officials. Mr. West's OMPF and OPF would help provide the public with a better understanding of military and civilian-guided research on this subject during the Korean War.

This request is not being made for commercial purposes. All documents will be provided to the general public without charge.

In the event that there are fees, I am willing to pay up to $250. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

I look forward to your response within 20 working days, as the statute requires. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Sincerely,

Robert Skvarla, Jr.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: NPRC JW 8.7.23
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am following up on a request sent under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. subsection 552, on August 8, 2023. I have not received a response identifying a request number and thus cannot provide that information at this time.

In my original request, attached, I asked for the Official Military Personnel File (OMPF) and Official Personnel Folder (OPF) for Louis Jolyon West (October 6, 1924 – January 2, 1999; SSN 395-16-2395). Mr. West served in the United States Air Force (USAF) between approximately 1948 and 1956 and worked as a civilian contractor for the USAF at the 3700th USAF Hospital at the Lackland Air Force Base after that.  I am reproducing a copy of the New York Times obituary I attached to the original request.

By law, 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(i), agencies are required to make a determination within 20 working days of a request. Given that the request was sent on August 8th, at least 49 working days have passed as of the date of the correspondence and as such, I am requesting an update on the status of my request. This includes both a request number and time frame for processing.

I am also renewing my request for a fee waiver. I am a member of the news media and request classification as such. My bylines, which include Unicorn Riot, the Geopolitical Economy Report, and Creem Magazine, can be found in both print and electronic publications. Please take note of the Office of Management and Budget guidelines published March 27, 1987 (52 FR 10012) that include electronic publications and other nontraditional publishers as representatives of the news media.

A fee waiver is appropriate in situations where "disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations and activities of the government, and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester,” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(iii). Mr. West, per the attached obituary, was a figure of considerable public interest. He worked for the government, both during his time in the USAF and as a civilian contractor, during the Korean War, on research related to the alleged brainwashing of American prisoners-of-war by Korean, Soviet, and Chinese officials. Mr. West's OMPF and OPF would help provide the public with a better understanding of military and civilian-guided research on this subject during the Korean War.

Sincerely,

Robert Skvarla, Jr.

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: State of Virginia Salaries 2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:


State of Virginia Fiscal Year 2023 Compensation Data for All Employees
Please provide the following fields for each employee in the dataset: 
Employee # | FIrst Name | Middle Name/Initial | Last Name | Employee Role Title | Position Number | Agency Name | Agency Location | Agency Address | Agency City/State/ZIP | Employee Category | Compensation (Base Pay, Salary, Hourly Rate, Total Pay, etc) | Overtime | Benefits Pay | Date Hired | Date Terminated | FT/PT 

Note:  If not all fields listed above are releasable as public record or available please disregard those individual fields for this request.

I would prefer the request be filled electronically, by either e-mail attachment or FTP Download if available, otherwise sent through mail via CD/DVD. I would appreciate the request to be filled in an accessible format, including but not limited to: CSV, Excel, Microsoft Access database, or other bulk list file type.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

communications.subject: RE: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: State of Virginia Salaries 2023
communications.communication: Good afternoon, I just had a couple questions regarding the data provided. I was curious if this dataset is representative of the 2023 fiscal year (from 7/1/2022 - 6/30/2023) as requested, or if the data provided was an as-of "snapshot" based on the report run date? I ask because it appears there are several employees with "Company Seniority Dates" and "Employees State Begin Dates" beyond the 2023 fiscal year. Can you also clarify which field should be considered the Employee Start Date, and may we also get a list of non-abbreviated "Companies"?

communications.subject: RE: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: State of Virginia Salaries 2023
communications.communication:
Good morning, 

I wanted to follow up on my previous email from 8/30 regarding the effective date of the data provided as well as a list of non-abbreviated "Companies". 

I also wanted to inquire about a record count discrepancy between this data and data previously released by this office in response to a separate request for 2022 employee compensation data. 2022's data had over 110,000 employee records released while this year has about 55,000 employee records. Looking at some specific employees existing in 2022 that do not exist in the 2023 data, it appears that most of those records belong to "Faculty, University Staff, and Political Jurisdiction Staff" with record counts of those classifications having the approximate record count of the difference between the two files. 

Would you be able to clarify the effective date of the data (FY 2023 as requested, or a snapshot in time as of the run of the report), as well as the field that could be considered Employee Start Date? Would it be possible to include these records in the 2023 disclosure as they were provided in response to a separate request for 2022 employee compensation data?  If you could a "key" between the company abbreviation provided and their non-abbreviated descriptions/names, that would also be greatly appreciated. 

Best,
Tyler

title: Missouri Drug Free Zone Sentence Information (Missouri Highway Patrol)

communications.subject: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request: Missouri Drug Free Zone Sentence Information (Missouri Highway Patrol)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Missouri Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of all records related to persons serving drug free zone law sentence enhancements– as mentioned in Missouri Revised Statutes 579.030, 579.055, 579.065.3(11)  – in the state of Missouri on the state and local levels. These records should, if available, state names, date of conviction, inmate ID and parole eligibility date and any demographic data that has been collected.  I am specifically looking for records from 2015 to the date that this request is processed.

In addition, I am requesting a copy of any and all reports or studies generated by the state that discuss the passage and efficacy of the drug free zone law.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jenny Wadhwa

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P044805-103023
communications.communication:
Dear Jenny Wadhwa: 
Our office received your open records request pursuant to Missouri's Sunshine Law, Chapter 610, RSMo. Your request has been assigned number P044805-103023. The Patrol is committed to adhering to the Sunshine Law and to ensuring that the public obtains access to open records that are not otherwise closed by law. The Sunshine Law requires each public agency to adhere to certain standards. This letter is designed to ensure that you understand our process for fulfilling your records request. Three Business Day Notice Requirement: 
The requested records are not immediately available for dissemination or inspection. The Patrol is required to notify you that additional research time will be required to fulfill the request. This correspondence satisfies the Sunshine Law's notice requirement within the required three business day period. Section 610.023.3, RSMo. 
 Additional Research Time is Required: 
The Patrol receives thousands of open records requests each month. Our Patrol Records Division personnel are dedicated to meeting the intent of Missouri's Sunshine Law and strive to respond to each request in a timely manner. The Patrol operates in all 114 Missouri counties and the independent city of St. Louis. Accordingly, many records maintained by the agency are not centrally located within, or immediately accessible to, the Patrol's Custodian of Records in Jefferson City. Our staff must research your request and ensure that we have captured all responsive records  ̶  regardless of their location within the agency. The research process is time-consuming, but we will make every effort to expedite your request. Estimated Time for Completion: 
The majority of our requests are fulfilled within thirty business days. Some requests require additional research time due to their scope or complexity. Our team will conduct an initial review of your request. If we estimate that the request will be fulfilled within thirty business days, we will not send an updated time estimate. However, if we estimate that the request will take longer than thirty business days, we will provide an updated time estimate that provides a detailed justification for the additional research time. Billing: 
As it relates to billing, Missouri law allows the Patrol to charge fees for copies and research time. Specifically, "[r]esearch time required for fulfilling records requests may be charged at the actual cost of research time." Section 610.026, RSMo. The Missouri Supreme Court recently determined that "staff time is the time required to provide access to public records maintained on computer facilities, recording tapes or disks, videotapes or films, pictures, maps, slides, graphics, illustrations or similar audio or visual items". Gross v. Parson, 624 S.W.3d 877, 884-89 (Mo. 2021) (internal quotations omitted). 
The Patrol will never bill you for redaction time or any research time conducted by our legal staff. You will only be charged for copies and staff research time as permitted by Missouri law. Please let us know if you have questions related to the billing estimate. 
Our team will forward a bill estimate to your attention once we have calculated the permissible costs and fees. The Patrol will not provide the responsive records until receipt of payment. Section 610.026.2, RSMo. 
We appreciate your patience as we review, research, and fulfill your open records request. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you will receive an email when your request has been completed. If you wish to withdraw or clarify your request, or if you have questions, please call our office at (573) 526-6146, or (573) 526-6167. 
 
Sincerely, 
Gerard G. Callahan 
Custodian of Records

title: 1033 MOU and annual inventory form (New York)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: 1033 MOU and annual inventory form (New York)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

-The current memorandum of agreement (MOA) or memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Defense Logistics Agency, Disposition Services regarding the 1033 equipment surplus program administered by the DLA Law Enforcement Support Office

-The annual inventory form required to be completed by MSP by the state coordinator of the 1033 program

According to the DLA FAQ page regarding the 1033 program, yours is the agency in charge of coordinating the 1033 program for the state. See http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/Pages/StateCoordinatorList.aspx

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Fengyue Hu

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: 1033 MOU and annual inventory form (New York)
communications.communication:
Dear Fengyue Hu:



This will acknowledge receipt of your request for records under the Freedom of Information Law received by the Division of Criminal Justice Services on October 11, 2023. The request was for "-The current memorandum of agreement (MOA) or memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Defense Logistics Agency, Disposition Services regarding the 1033 equipment surplus program administered by the DLA Law Enforcement Support Office

-The annual inventory form required to be completed by MSP by the state coordinator of the 1033 program

According to the DLA FAQ page regarding the 1033 program, yours is the agency in charge of coordinating the 1033 program for the state. See http://www.dispositionservices.dla.mil/leso/Pages/StateCoordinatorList.aspx

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.".



Your request has been forwarded to the appropriate program area(s) to identify documents that are responsive to your request and which may be made available pursuant to all applicable provisions of the Freedom of Information Law.



A determination as to whether your request is granted or denied will be reached in approximately 20 business days or we will notify you in writing if the responsible program area(s) should require additional time to locate, assemble and review documents that may be responsive to your request.



Please note that, pursuant to Article 6 of the Public Officers Law, a charge may be applied to your request, including the actual cost of the medium used to respond to your Freedom of Information Law request and/or other related costs.  When responsive records have been identified, you will be informed of any cost and how payment should be made.







Very truly yours,




Brian Garvey, Esq.
Records Access Officer

communications.subject: FW: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: 1033 MOU and annual inventory form (New York)
communications.communication:
Dear Fengyue Hu:

This is in response to your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request to the Division of Criminal Justice Services (DCJS) seeking the "current memorandum of agreement (MOA) or memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Defense Logistics Agency, Disposition Services regarding the 1033 equipment surplus program administered by the DLA Law Enforcement Support Office [and the] the annual inventory form required to be completed by MSP [sic] by the state coordinator of the 1033 program."

In response to your request, attached is the current memorandum of agreement (MOA) or memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Defense Logistics Agency, Disposition Services regarding the 1033 equipment surplus program administered by the DLA Law Enforcement Support Office.
In response to your request for the annual inventory form required to be completed by the MSP (we assume you mean NY) by the state coordinator of the 1033 program, this form no longer exists. All equipment inventories are listed quarterly on the DLA LESO Public Information page linked below.  On the LESO public information page click on "ALASKA - WYOMING AND US TERRITORIES" for a downloadable EXCEL listing of property held by all participating states and territories. https://www.dla.mil/DispositionServices/Offers/Reutilization/LawEnforcement/PublicInformation/

Pursuant to POL §89(4)(a), you may appeal this determination within 30 days to the Counsel, Division of Criminal Justice Services, 80 South Swan St., Albany, NY 12210 or by email at foil@dcjs.ny.gov<mailto:foil@dcjs.ny.gov>.

Very truly yours,

Gina L. Bianchi, Esq.
for
Brian Garvey, Esq.
Records Access Officer

communications.subject: [Records Center] Public Records Request :: R150702-102323
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

RE: OPEN RECORDS REQUEST of October 23, 2023., Reference # R150702-102323. 
Dear Cole Howard, 
Gwinnett County received an open records request from you on October 23, 2023. Your request mentioned: "To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

All records, reports, body cam footage and other audio or video recordings related to the death of Heather Faye Besco Johnston. Mrs. Johnston died on or around July 3, 2021. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Cole Howard 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fgwinnett-county-police-department-641%252Fheather-johnston-death-police-gwinnett-county-police-department-152976%252F%253Femail%253Dpoliceopenrecords%252540gwinnettcounty.com&url_auth_token=AAAcIeS2fls9et_QcPctuAXe1ro%3A1quoVU%3AwtgX9D1elbny5j5gR8vjHLL7SdGQAa4k3HIh-zDKfqY" 
Gwinnett County has reviewed its files and has located responsive records to your request. Portions of the records requested are exempt from disclosure under the Georgia Open Records Act andhave been [redacted or excluded] for the following reasons: 
O.C.G.A. § 50-18-72(a)(26.2)-Audio and video recordings from devices used by law enforcement officers in a place where there is a reasonable expectation of privacy when there is no pending investigation. 
Please log in to the Open Records Center at the following link to retrieve the appropriate responsive documents. Public Records Request - R150702-102323 Gwinnett County Public Records Center 
 
  * Click on My Request Center 
  * Click on View My Requests - Choose the request you want to view. 
  * Click on View Files 
 
  * Your request will open, and any files/attachments associated with the request. Click on the title of the document you wish to download from the “Files” box. 
  *  If you are using Chrome as your browser, the documents will download at the bottom of the screen. You will need to click on the document(s) at the bottom of the screen once it downloads to open/view the file. If the files do not appear to be downloading, please check your firewall and pop-up blocker settings. Note: 
If you have any questions or need additional information, please feel free to contact my office at 770-513-5209. 
Sincerely, 
Ryan Winderweedle 
Cpl 
Police PIO (News Media Only)

title: Open Records Request: Bush & Rawlins Metadata

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Open Records Request: Bush & Rawlins Metadata
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Metadata for all email communications sent or received, including being CCed or BCCed, which contain both John Bush and Wayne Rawlins (Wayne@waynerawlins.com) between 3/24/2022 and 10/25/23.

The specific metadata data points I'm interested in are: to address(es), from address, cc address(es), bcc address(es), sent date/time, received date/time, subject line, and names of all attachments. This request does not seek the contents of the emails themselves, and only the specified email metadata. Please do not include duplicate emails. Please provide me with the records in an Excel format.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

e

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Victor Gotbaum
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records relating to, mentioning, or generated as a result of investigation into Victor H. Gotbaum (September 5, 1921 - April 5, 2015). Proof of death is not required as his death was widely reported: https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/06/nyregion/victor-gotbaum-labor-leader-who-helped-save-new-york-from-bankruptcy-dies-at-93.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies at FBI Headquarters. Please also conduct a search for records at the Alexandria Records Center. If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Paul Galante

    Upload documents directly:
    https://https://www.muckrock.comhttps://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?url_auth_token=AAAj2ProGzquHYFeb-SMkiAXsEc%3A1iZtWO%3AP5o0DZBFji_nW1nrbiCghm7Jjs8&next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Ffederal-bureau-of-investigation-10%252Fvictor-gotbaum-83846%252F%253Femail%253Defoia%252540subscriptions.fbi.gov

Supporting documentation **

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to
foipaquestions@fbi.gov. If you have received a FOIPA request number, please
include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

** 

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBI’s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBI’s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the ‘Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request tool’ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1453318-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@ic.fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 138 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 571 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,289 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,649 days for processing.

Respectfully,


Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
F: (540) 868-4391
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1453318-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on “Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request” on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI’s FOIPA Program is searching the FBI’s indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 122 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 1,230 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 2,010 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 2,370 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

title: Public Records Request: Violent Crime Intervention Fund

communications.subject: Tennessee Public Records Act Request: Public Records Request: Violent Crime Intervention Fund
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

According to documents released by the State of Tennessee, the Chatanooga Police Department received $1,631,583 in funding awarded in 2022 from the Violent Crime Intervention Fund: https://www.tn.gov/content/dam/tn/finance/ocjp/VCIF%20Funding%20Plan.pdf

Pursuant to the Tennessee Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of all documents, including but not limited to, applications, agreements, and reporting documents related to the $1,631,583 received as part of the 2022 Violent Crime Intervention Fund.  

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kent Hoover, a citizen of Tennessee, in coordination with e.

According to documents released by the State of Tennessee, the Chatanooga Police Department received $1,631,583 in funding awarded in 2022 from the Violent Crime Intervention Fund: https://www.tn.gov/content/dam/tn/finance/ocjp/VCIF%20Funding%20Plan.pdf

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: BlueLeaks (Jacksonville Sheriff's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. Documents mentioning, describing or generated in response to the BlueLeaks release, the preceding hack or subsequent fallout, including but not limited to:

* Damage assessments
* Emails
* Interagency communications (local, state, or federal)
* Communications with the press about BlueLeaks
* Communications with Twitter or other social media or sharing platforms

2. Documents mentioning or describing Distributed Denial of Secrets (DDoSecrets)

You may limit this request to records generated between November 1, 2018 and the present.

I am a member of the news media and request classification as such. I have previously written about the government and its activities, with some reaching over 100,000 readers in outlets such as Gizmodo, MuckRock, Motherboard, Property of the People, Unicorn Riot, and The Outline, among others. As such, as I have a reasonable expectation of publication and my editorial and writing skills are well established. In addition, I discuss and comment on the files online and make them available through non-profits such as the library Internet Archive and the journalist non-profit MuckRock, disseminating them to a large audience. While my research is not limited to this, a great deal of it, including this, focuses on the activities and attitudes of the government itself. As such, it is not necessary for me to demonstrate the relevance of this particular subject in advance.

As my primary purpose is to inform about government activities by reporting on it and making the raw data available, I request that fees be waived.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Emma Best

title: Request to NASA for 2021 film collaborations

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request to NASA for 2021 film collaborations
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A list of all the films that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) has participated in the production of, in any capacity whatsoever, for the year 2021. Any and all such lists, full or partial, would be appreciated and may include, but are not limited to, entertainment liaison (ELO) reports. I request that you search for these documents in any location where they might be located, including but not limited to the entertainment liaison offices and communications HQ.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo
